text:
_Q1:_ Link from both but only if relevant aka list of tools or similar. If you look at your G Anaalytics, you'll notice people find their way to the Pricing page quite easily anyway if they're truly interested.

Q2: "_Within the whole cluster (including the pillar article), do you only link back to the one single feature page (and stay away from linking to other feature pages?)._" again, make sure everything is STRONGLY RELATED [ads and email marketing are not related if you're writing a post on ads only so while you might mention email marketing, you don't necessarily need to link to the feature page]. From my experience though, this isn't super important. I've tested both having dozens of links to features in one article and only keeping one or two and the results are similar. Try experimenting with your related posts at the end of each article though.

text: As a strategist and writer, besides what everyone mentioned, also keep an eye on the degree of references they put in. Are they mentioning fewer studies and complex concepts or not reaching out to experts anymore? They might still put in a great effort into the piece but what I mentioned can give it that wow factor

text:
<@U011QQDDSJV>, we do the site: search whenever we publish anything new or update old articles. We also started using Ahrefs internal link opportunities report for that.

The challenge I see here is that it "destroys" the idea of clusters, at least the idea our SEO folks had – where the clusters are nicely separate, silo'd, and not overlapping.

text:
Follow up question to this:

Should search intent affect what goes into the topic cluster? Just got a recommendation to only create a cluster with the same search intent & not link outside of it.

elements.text:

text: <@UQ3Q7SQ6A> what do you mean by the "same" search intent? Do you mean by topic? The way you'd want to think about clusters would likely include every level of search intent when it comes to a product / service. Like this:

text:
One of the seos told us we shouldn't mix 'how to topics' with 'what is' in the same cluster. This sounds so wrong to me.

Re. Internal linking outside the cluster, here's what they've shared "While there may be some exceptions, in the realm of topic clusters, you are wise to keep the bulk of your interlinking under the same pillar content." <https://www.searchenginejournal.com/topic-clusters-on-site-seo/319109/|https://www.searchenginejournal.com/topic-clusters-on-site-seo/319109/>

attachments.title: Why (& How) Topic Clusters Are Your Most Powerful SEO Weapon
attachments.text: Find out how topic clusters can be the catalyst that launches your website to the top of the search engine results pages.
attachments.fallback: Search Engine Journal: Why (& How) Topic Clusters Are Your Most Powerful SEO Weapon

text: Maybe another way to look at this is to create smaller clusters, with only several posts in each

elements.text: Maybe another way to look at this is to create smaller clusters, with only several posts in each

text:
>  One of the seos told us we shouldn’t mix ‘how to topics’ with ‘what is’ in the same cluster. This sounds so wrong to me.
It does indeed. Clustering content around the same topic makes sense. Interlink it well, and ideally put it all in one subfolder because that makes for a good information architecture. But it’s totally natural to link to other topics if they’re related. For instance, if I’m adding content to a cluster about Shopify, I’m going to link to other Shopify content, but to my Magento article too. And while I’m at it, I’ll link to and article about faceted navigation because it’s relevant and natural. The links add value to the article, and that’s what I’d always keep in mind.

text: Sounds like you've had some ROUGH folks working on SEO, haha. Can you imagine writing an article about what is tin roofing, and you have an article on how to install tin roofing, but you never talk about that or even link to it? In no world does that make sense, haha. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Sounds like you've had some ROUGH folks working on SEO, haha. Can you imagine writing an article about what is tin roofing, and you have an article on how to install tin roofing, but you never talk about that or even link to it? In no world does that make sense, haha.

text:
My thoughts exactly. I come from the "user" perspective on this & only now move toward SEO.

So in our case, the cluster would be around email marketing. We're sitting on ca. 100 posts about it, and other related topics landing pages/lead generation/funnel marketing/etc. It's tricky to maintain the balance here, trying to juggle their suggestions and our perspective.

Ideally, I would just create a giant cluster (or a few) around email marketing, trying linking to mainly content within the cluster, but when it's natural – also link outside.

text:
Hey folks!

Has anyone ever experienced a decline in their blog DA? My company's DA is 84 (Ahrefs) and I recently found that it used to be 86 (sometime in 2015). This is my first time experiencing something like this. Can anyone guide me to the reason behind this decline and what can be done to improve and strengthen the DA without any more set backs? I'm tagging <@UUXMCJQ15> but please jump in this convo.

Thanks!
